content: @Tejas Tank mentioned https://github.com/zulip/zulip/pull/14326/commits/1e3f2dd7b8e75eaeffb8f97bdf5d8d1c96beb2c9 in another topic recently. The issue is "Add user to stream" interface was hard to find. If you have a short monitor and go to edit a stream, the UI for adding users (i.e. subscribers) is below the fold. That whole UI is cluttered. (It has other issues, too, but I don't want to go too far down the rabbit hole.)
This would be a really nice issue to fix, so I'm starting a conversation about the best way to fix it.

I think the problem is that we don't normally expect the search and add functionality to be at the same level besides each other, with search
displayed before add. Also as mentioned somewhere, the term Add is not intuitive. Another problem is that the first section of stream settings i.e. the section till before the email address, perfectly fills the screen and the overlay, causing us to think that there are no more settings, while in fact there are more when scrolled down.

What I have in mind is:
1) Move the stream membership section to the top
2) Rename the "Add" button to "Subscribe"(maybe?) and place this where the current search bar is
3) Implement the search functionality like its been implemented everywhere else , using a search icon which toggles the search text. This may require changing the list a little to make it "go" with the changes.
This is what I feel.

Yeah, Sorry. Just had the idea and typed it immediately without looking at it in detail.
I hate pretty much everything about the split-panel UI for streams, if I can be honest.

When you're adding/creating a stream, the left side is just taking up super valuable real estate (which contributes to the problem at hand here).

And when you're browsing streams, the right side is just blank and looks stupid.

Steve Howell said:

When you're adding/creating a stream, the left side is just taking up super valuable real estate (which contributes to the problem at hand here).

And when you're browsing streams, the right side is just blank and looks stupid.

Yes.
According to you, what would be the best view for such situations?

I'd eliminate the split panel, and then I'd make more columns. So instead of this:

image.png

...I'd have it all in one line:

checkmark | hash icon | 14157 | weird graph thing | **anounce** | Stuff everyone should see (Everyone...)
And then when you clicked on something to edit it, it would take up the whole modal.
And then I don't know exactly how I'd take advantage of the width in the edit-modal to solve the below-the-fold problem.
For creating a stream, I actually think a wizard-like interface makes sense.

And then for editing a stream, I think you could probably have a tabbed interface with "Properties" and "Subscribers". Usually you're either changing properties or adding subscribers to a stream, but not both.

Note that the right sidebar also contains a bunch of information about stream permissions and notification settings that we couldn't reasonably fit in a card without significant design changes. I think moving that UI to a modal would make it a lot less usable to adjust personal notification settings.

My general design thoughts for that page are that there are 3 types of settings (personal/notification settings, stream-level/permissions settings, and subscribers), and we should do a better job of organizing them. I certainly thing the stream settings, which are already in a modal aside from name/description, should all live in that modal (getting rid of the content-editable widget)
I think the most useful next step to improve that UI would be to move "Subscribers" to a separate panel, since it'll make working on the rest of it a lot easier mentally.

Tim Abbott said:

I think moving that UI to a modal would make it a lot less usable to adjust personal notification settings.

What's the exact use case here? Is the idea that you're auditing a bunch of your streams at once for their settings (so you don't want to zoom in and out, so to speak)?
Yes, exactly.
It's possible that use case will be reduced with changes we have planned to "notification settings" to provide a nice list on that page.
In fairness, I never touch any of the 7 notification settings, which probably biases me against the split-panel more than some people. But, yeah, they could be represented by icons in the left side.

I fully support a Subscribers tab as an incremental step. And if we had that, you should be able to click here to open the subscribers tab:

image.png

BTW there's two major stream/notification settings PRs, #14296 and #14066 from @Ryan Rehman and @Pragati Agrawal, which together I expect to make us much better prepared for further work on stream-level notification settings.

I actually like the split screen UI, it just need a better UX design. A quick mockup -
Frame-1.png

@Tejas Tank That's a nice looking mockup! For the View/Add/Delete/Search buttons, I'm not sure those need to be super prominent. I'm not exactly sure what "Search" means.

For "Members" and "Settings", would it make sense to have those be tabs?
image.png

@Steve Howell The search would be similar to view stream button but will focus on the search bar after switching to the channel. And for the terms, I just named them what came to my mind.
image.png
Like the image attached to the issue, it says "Stream membership", "Stream subscribers" would be nice here.

For question regarding usage of tabs, we should restrict the amount of different components we use in a particular view. Like we are already using "collapse" bars and split views, adding tabs would increase the amount of nested components.
Hope the above message makes some sense :sweat_smile:

I'm not convinced we need a quick link from search settings to our main search bar, but that's a small detail in your proposal and not worth a ton of debate at this point. (I can see the use case, to be clear.)

As for names (membership vs. subscribers), I'm also not super opinionated on those.

Tejas Tank said:

For question regarding usage of tabs, we should restrict the amount of different components we use in a particular view. Like we are already using "collapse" bars and split views, adding tabs would increase the amount of nested components.

I don't think we should constrain ourselves in this particular way. As long as collapse bars, split views, and tabs all accomplish what they're supposed to do from a UI perspective, I think they're valid choices to make. (I do agree that having a bunch of different UI elements could be a design smell of sorts, but I think we can address that without actually constraining ourselves by saying "too many different types of design elements is bad".)

Tabbed views are no doubt good but are mostly used by parents (bigger) elements to switch view. If we use tabbed view for a child elements to switch a nested elements it can cause usability issues on smaller screens. Like we have three elements - About, Settings, Members. Using accordion/collapse element here can give each of the header proper spacing, tabs would just get crumbled on smaller screens. As you can see the search and add elements having no space on smaller views. image.png

So I'm mostly proposing this for when you're editing stream. I don't think you need "About", so the only two tabs are "Settings" and "Subscribers", which should fit easily. All the width-related problems are solvable:

  • use concise headings with hover titles for normal screens
  • go to icons with hover titles for narrow screens

The settings panel would look like this:

image.png

And the subscribers subpanel would like this:

image.png

Also, as I mentioned earlier, if we can handle notifications better (either just use icons in what's now the left-side view or manage them elsewhere in the app), then I'd just eliminate the whole left/right split-screen paradigm, which would make the edit-stream experience a lot more roomy.

Why I made the about panel collapsible was to get proper real estate for other components. So if I open Settings, the about panel will collapse. This will provide all the area to settings menu and this would eliminate the need to scroll making the interactions fast, ease of access.
It's not clear to me how collapse panels lead to any fewer clicks than tabs.
Based on the image you posted, I think you're imagining something different than I'm actually proposing--that could be part of the disconnect here.
I think collapse panels take two click to switch between panels, correct? And they take up just as much real estate as tabs (actually more if you have 3)?

What I have in mind would be similar to how we handle the three categories of bots. I know the problems aren't completely analogous, but they're similar. Would you prefer collapse panels for the bots UI, out of curiosity, @Tejas Tank?

image.png

I'd been thinking more along the lines of having 3 tabs beneath the name/description

  • Personal settings (The current default view with a few things removed)
  • Global settings (Would be the current "[Change]" modal)
  • Susbcribers
Which would be a simpler design change and also potentially a bit cleaner for browsing since it could remember you're on the "Members" tab as you click around.
Screenshot_20200526-000237.jpg

Are you sure about adding nested tabs? As far as I have read nested tabs provide bad UX, as we already has a tab on left side for "Subscribed Streams" and "All Streams".

We could add an accordion as attached above.
(wait, nvm, I think I have it wrong)

I think an accordian isn't very usable for this sort of thing; it forces you to click to open things. There are common use cases of "Clicking through 15 streams looking at the subscribers list" or "Clicking through 15 streams looking at the settings" that we should aim to make work nicely.
@Tim Abbott We can have the first accordion open by default :thinking:
Yes, but what if you want a different one open by default? The tabs model supports that nicely, and the accordian really doesn't.
Um...okay. Then do we want to keep the quick access features? (i.e.- View, Join, Add, Delete)
As I've said before, I think we should make that UI have a tab-switcher between 3 tabs: Personal settings, Stream settings, and Subscribers.
As I think that solves the UX problems we have with the existing widgets.

The first step I'd take in this direction would be to replace the content-editable widgets for changing the stream name/description with moving those to the "Change" modal (I think we can just change the click handler for the pencils, visually). We'll want to do that regardless of what path forward we take, and it'll simplify the problem.
